query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Così discesi del cerchio primaio 2 giù nel secondo, che men loco cinghia 3 e tanto più dolor, che punge a guaio.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Thus I descended from the first circle 2 down into the second, which girds a smaller space 3 and so much more pain, that it stings to lament.
**Cornish:**
1 Vel dhiskynnaf a'n kynsa kelgh 2 isel dhe'n nessa, a syns le a-ves 3 ha moy a boen, ow tisplegya dhe wela.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
4 Stavvi Minòs orribilmente, e ringhia: 5 essamina le colpe ne l’intrata; 6 giudica e manda secondo ch’avvinghia.
query.result:
**English:**
4 There Minos stands, horribly, and snarls: 5 he examines the sins at the entrance; 6 he judges and sends forth according to how he entwines himself.
**Cornish:**
4 Ynno Minos ow sevel yn erghus, ha grownya: 5 ev a breuf an pechodhow bys an fordh; 6 ev a varnas ha kas avel orth yma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Dico che quando l’anima mal nata 8 li vien dinanzi, tutta si confessa; 9 e quel conoscitor de le peccata
10 vede qual loco d’inferno è da essa; 11 cignesi con la coda tante volte 12 quantunque gradi vuol che giù sia messa.
query.result:
**English:**
7 I say that when the ill-born soul 8 comes before him, it confesses everything; 9 and that knower of sins
10 sees what place in hell is for it; 11 he lashes it with his tail as many times 12 as the number of steps he wants it to be cast down.
**Cornish:**
7 Me a lever orth an enef vyth vyth 8 yth dheuth ragdho, oll a gonfessya; 9 hagena gonessor an pekatha
10 a wel orth le mayn yn enef a-ugh; 11 a-ugh a gisn gans y foel kemmys gweyth 12 vel orth an radh a vynna y vos lemmys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Sempre dinanzi a lui ne stanno molte: 14 vanno a vicenda ciascuna al giudizio, 15 dicono e odono e poi son giù volte.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Many always stand before him: 14 they go in turn, each to the judgement, 15 they speak and listen and then they are turned away.
**Cornish:**
13 Purtreus orto anjea vyth: 14 ymons yn-unn pub on dhe'n breus, 15 ymons owth leverel hagena ow kelmys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 «O tu che vieni al doloroso ospizio», 17 disse Minòs a me quando mi vide, 18 lasciando l’atto di cotanto offizio,
19 «guarda com’ entri e di cui tu ti fide; 20 non t’inganni l’ampiezza de l’intrare!».
query.result:
**English:**
16 "O you who come to the sorrowful hospice," 17 Minos said to me when he saw me, 18 leaving the act of his great office,
19 "be careful how you enter and in whom you trust; 20 do not let the wideness of the entrance deceive you!"
**Cornish:**
16 "O ty ow tos dhe'n chi an-lowen dolorus," 17 a leveris Minos dhym pan welyas, 18 ow kelli ow breus a'y offis mawr,
19 "sel an-lowen ha'gas ow tos ha bos; 20 na wra'gas ankoweth an-lowen ow tos!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
21 E ’l duca mio a lui: «Perché pur gride?
22 Non impedir lo suo fatale andare: 23 vuolsi così colà dove si puote 24 ciò che si vuole, e più non dimandare».
query.result:
**English:**
21 And my guide to him: "Why do you cry out?
22 Do not impede his fated journey:
23 it is desired thus, there where one can
24 do what one wants, and ask no more".
**Cornish:**
21 Ha'gas ow th'oghen: "Peragras whylef?"
22 Na lettya y dha fatel anedha:
23 Yma yw an kevrith ena, le may
24 Gweles an kevrith, ha na dh'ober moy".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Or incomincian le dolenti note 26 a farmisi sentire; or son venuto 27 là dove molto pianto mi percuote.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Now the sorrowful notes begin
26 to make themselves heard to me; now I have come
27 to where much weeping strikes me.
**Cornish:**
25 Wosa, an notennow dolennow
26 A wra dhemedhes dhe'm klevos; wosa
27 Y'm le may le mayns a'm tasow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Io venni in loco d’ogne luce muto, 29 che mugghia come fa mar per tempesta, 30 se da contrari venti è combattuto.
query.result:
**English:**
28 I came to a place of all light mute, 29 that roars as the sea does in a tempest, 30 if it is fought by contrary winds.
**Cornish:**
28 Yth pys vy dhe'gas oll golow munys, 29 aga growl avel mar a-berth mos, 30 mar peus gwynsow gwyns a-gas omladh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 La bufera infernal, che mai non resta, 32 mena li spirti con la sua rapina; 33 voltando e percotendo li molesta.
query.result:
**English:**
31 The infernal storm, that never rests, 32 drives the spirits with its violence; 33 turning and striking, it torments them.
**Cornish:**
31 An gwynsow uffernal, nag esa byth, 32 a-gas an sperysis gans y dowr, 33 ow tos ha bos ha'gas omladh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Quando giungon davanti a la ruina, 35 quivi le strida, il compianto, il lamento; 36 bestemmian quivi la virtù divina.
query.result:
**English:**
34 When they arrive in front of the ruin, 35 there are screams, weeping, and wailing; 36 there they blaspheme the divine power.
**Cornish:**
34 Pan vons yn-rag dhe'n dinythyans, 35 eno henna strifow, an kevyow, hag an golhow; 36 eno henna hen golh an gallos dywynn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Intesi ch’a così fatto tormento 38 enno dannati i peccator carnali, 39 che la ragion sommettono al talento.
query.result:
**English:**
37 I heard that carnal sinners are tormented in this way, 38 those who submit reason to desire.
**Cornish:**
37 Me a glewas bos marow an poenans ma, 38 an pechoryon karnek, 39 a wra'n ow resennow orth y'n talen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 E come li stornei ne portan l’ali 41 nel freddo tempo, a schiera larga e piena, 42 così quel fiato li spiriti mali
43 di qua, di là, di giù, di sù li mena; 44 nulla speranza li conforta mai, 45 non che di posa, ma di minor pena.
query.result:
**English:**
40 And as the starlings bear their wings 41 in the cold season, in a large and full flock, 42 so that wind leads the evil spirits
43 from here, from there, from below, from above; 44 no hope ever comforts them, 45 not even of rest, but of lesser pain.
**Cornish:**
40 Ha kevel orth an sterens y porth aga'n askel 41 yn termyn y yen, yn skwyer bras ha leun, 42 hemma an eneval a'n spyrysow drog
43 a-dhia, a-dhyworth, a-woles, a-ucha, 44 nyns yw gwynans bythkweth aga'n cusul, 45 nag eus a-dhia pos, mes a-dhia poen bihan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 E come i gru van cantando lor lai, 47 faccendo in aere di sé lunga riga, 48 così vid’ io venir, traendo guai,
49 ombre portate da la detta briga; 50 per ch’i’ dissi: «Maestro, chi son quelle 51 genti che l’aura nera sì gastiga?».
query.result:
**English:**
46 And as the cranes go singing their lai, 47 making a long line of themselves in the air, 48 so I saw coming, wailing in their woe,
49 shades borne by the aforementioned storm; 50 so that I said: "Master, who are those 51 people that the black wind so punishes?".
**Cornish:**
46 Ha kevel orth an gruysi ow kanna aga'n lay, 47 ow kul gwella yn ayr hir linya a-dhyworth aga'n honan, 48 hemma a welas vy ow tos, ow gulena yn aga'n poen,
49 ombew porthys gans an breus nessa; 50 rag hemma vy a leveris: "Mester, pyw yw henna 51 an dus a gastiga an awel du hemma?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 «La prima di color di cui novelle 53 tu vuo’ saper», mi disse quelli allotta, 54 «fu imperadrice di molte favelle.
query.result:
**English:**
52 "The first of those whose story 53 you want to know," he told me then, 54 "was empress of many tongues.
**Cornish:**
52 "An kynsa a'n liw henna a-dro'gas 53 ty a vynsi gweles," hemma a leveris vy ena, 54 "o veu empereres a liesow lies."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 A vizio di lussuria fu sì rotta, 56 che libito fé licito in sua legge, 57 per tòrre il biasmo in che era condotta.
query.result:
**English:**
55 By a vision of lust she was so overcome, 56 that she made desire lawful in her law, 57 in order to remove the blame in which she was held.
**Cornish:**
55 Dre lien lust o pedn fetha'gas re, 56 henna gwre libid licit y'n lagha, 57 rag torra an biasva yn aga vetha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Ell’ è Semiramìs, di cui si legge 59 che succedette a Nino e fu sua sposa: 60 tenne la terra che ’l Soldan corregge.
query.result:
**English:**
58 She is Semiramis, of whom one reads 59 that she succeeded Ninus and was his wife: 60 she held the land that the Sultan rules.
**Cornish:**
58 Hesi yw Semiramìs, a vydh leverys 59 ow hi a veu dhe Ninus ha'gas ow wraga: 60 hi a veu an pow an kever an Soldan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 L’altra è colei che s’ancise amorosa, 62 e ruppe fede al cener di Sicheo; 63 poi è Cleopatràs lussurïosa.
query.result:
**English:**
61 The other is she who killed herself for love, 62 and broke faith with the ashes of Sychaeus; 63 then there is lustful Cleopatra.
**Cornish:**
61 An aral hi yw an hini a omladhas rag karanteth, 62 ha'gas hi a dhorras feth dhe losow Sicheo; 63 wosa hi yw Kleopatràs an fylleth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Elena vedi, per cui tanto reo 65 tempo si volse, e vedi ’l grande Achille, 66 che con amore al fine combatteo.
query.result:
**English:**
64 See Helen, for whom so much evil 65 time passed, and see the great Achilles, 66 who in the end fought for love.
**Cornish:**
64 Gweles Elena, rag an kever kemmyskweth 65 amser a drehedhas, ha gweles an brassa Achille, 66 neb a omladhas dhe'n diwedh rag karanteth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Vedi Parìs, Tristano»; e più di mille 68 ombre mostrommi e nominommi a dito, 69 ch’amor di nostra vita dipartille.
query.result: **English:**67 See Paris, Tristan"; and more than a thousand68 shades he showed me and named them with his finger,69 whom love separated from our life.**Cornish:**67 Gweles Paris, Trystan"; ha moy es mil70 skewens a dhiskwedhas ha'n hanowas gans y benow,71 y'ga loves a dhiskwedhas dhyworth aga byw.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Poscia ch’io ebbi ’l mio dottore udito 71 nomar le donne antiche e ’ cavalieri, 72 pietà mi giunse, e fui quasi smarrito.
query.result:
**English:**
70 After I had heard my teacher 71 name the ancient ladies and knights, 72 pity seized me, and I was almost bewildered.
**Cornish:**
70 Wosa wosa vy esem klewys vy doktor 71 hemma an gwragedh koth ha'n chivalers, 72 pytas a dheuth dhe'm ha'm beu bronkys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 I’ cominciai: «Poeta, volontieri 74 parlerei a quei due che ’nsieme vanno, 75 e paion sì al vento esser leggeri».
query.result:
**English:**
73 I began: "Poet, I would gladly 74 speak to those two who go together, 75 and seem to be so light in the wind."
**Cornish:**
73 Me a dhalleth: "Bardh, a vynnafsa 74 kewsel dhe'n dew a wra a-wortha, 75 ha'gaswonvel orth y'n gwyns dhe'n gwyns."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Ed elli a me: «Vedrai quando saranno 77 più presso a noi; e tu allor li priega 78 per quello amor che i mena, ed ei verranno».
query.result:
**English:**
76 And he to me: "You will see when they are 77 nearer to us; and then you beg them 78 by that love which leads them, and they will come."
**Cornish:**
76 Ha'gaswon ev dhe'm: "Thy welo pan vo dhe'nsi 77 moyha dhe'n ni; ha'gaswon ena gorra 78 rag an garow ena a-mena, ha'gaswon dhe'nsi a dheuth."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Sì tosto come il vento a noi li piega, 80 mossi la voce: «O anime affannate, 81 venite a noi parlar, s’altri nol niega!».
query.result:
**English:**
79 As soon as the wind bends them toward us, 80 I raised my voice: "O weary souls, 81 come to speak with us, if no other forbids it!"
**Cornish:**
79 Kyns ages an gwyns a-dro dhe'n ni, 80 me a leveris vy leuv: "O enevalow trues, 81 deuth dhe'n ni rag kewsel, mar nyns yw gwrys gans neb aral!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 «O animal grazïoso e benigno 89 che visitando vai per l’aere perso 90 noi che tignemmo il mondo di sanguigno,
91 se fosse amico il re de l’universo, 92 noi pregheremmo lui de la tua pace, 93 poi c’hai pietà del nostro mal perverso.
query.result:
**English:**
88 "O gracious and gentle animal 89 who, visiting, pass through the lost air, 90 we who stained the world with blood,
91 if the king of the universe were our friend, 92 we would pray to him for your peace, 93 since you have pity for our perverse evil."
**Cornish:**
88 "O anoweth grasus ha da 89 ow tos owth owth an ayr kollas 90 ni ow a wra dha bys vyth gwydh,
91 mar bysya cara an myghtern bys 92 ni a wra pedn lowena dhe hedh, 93 rag ow a wra trues dhe ni ankoweth."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Di quel che udire e che parlar vi piace, 95 noi udiremo e parleremo a voi, 96 mentre che ’l vento, come fa, ci tace.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Of that which you like to hear and speak, 95 we will hear and speak to you, 96 while the wind, as it does, is silent for us.
**Cornish:**
94 A’gan klevs ha leverel a wra lowen, 95 ni a wra klevs ha leverel dhys, 96 tramor an gwyns, kepar ha wra, a wra mudh dhyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Siede la terra dove nata fui 98 su la marina dove ’l Po discende 99 per aver pace co’ seguaci sui.
query.result:
**English:**
97 The land where I was born is situated 98 on the coast where the Po River descends 99 to find peace with its followers.
**Cornish:**
97 An tir le mayth owth genys 98 war an mor le mayth an Dowr Po 99 rag kavos hedh gans y dhiskibion.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Amor, ch’al cor gentil ratto s’apprende, 101 prese costui de la bella persona 102 che mi fu tolta; e ’l modo ancor m’offende.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Love, which is quickly learned by the gentle heart, 101 took hold of him for the beautiful person 102 who was taken from me; and the manner still offends me.
**Cornish:**
100 Karanteth, ow a wra dyskys gans an kalon da, 101 a gemeras an den-ma na’n person brav 102 ow a veu kemeres dhym; ha’n fordh a wra gonis dhym.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Amor, ch’a nullo amato amar perdona, 104 mi prese del costui piacer sì forte, 105 che, come vedi, ancor non m’abbandona.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Love, which to no loved one allows not loving, 104 seized me with such desire for his pleasure, 105 that, as you see, it still does not abandon me.**Cornish:**
103 Karanteth, na'th onan karys karanteth, 104 a gemeras vy dhe'y pleser dhe-wla, 105 pub trawel, dell yw, ny wodha vy dhe-wla.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Amor condusse noi ad una morte. 107 Caina attende chi a vita ci spense». 108 Queste parole da lor ci fuor porte.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Love led us to one death. 107 Caina awaits him who took our lives." 108 These words were spoken to us by them.**Cornish:**
106 Karanteth a'n dug dhe unn ankow. 107 Keyn a wra dhe unn a wrug an bywnans. 108 An gerow ma a veu dasserghys dhynny.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Quand’ io intesi quell’ anime offense, 110 china’ il viso, e tanto il tenni basso, 111 fin che ’l poeta mi disse: «Che pense?».
query.result:
**English:**
109 When I heard those souls being offended, 110 I lowered my face, and kept it down, 111 until the poet said to me: "What are you thinking?".**Cornish:**
109 Pan vynnav an enevalow henna, 110 y’m gorra vy ajallen, ha’gas vy dhesel, 111 bys vy’n bardh a leveris dhym: “Pynsys vy?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Quando rispuosi, cominciai: «Oh lasso, 113 quanti dolci pensier, quanto disio 114 menò costoro al doloroso passo!».
query.result:
**English:**
112 When I answered, I began: "Oh, woe, 113 how many sweet thoughts, how much desire 114 brought these people to the sorrowful pass!"
**Cornish:**
112 Pan wrugav, me a dhallathas: "Oh, meskin, 113 pyth poesowena dowr, pyth a-gannas 114 a dhiskwedhas an dussergh an pass!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Poi mi rivolsi a loro e parla’ io, 116 e cominciai: «Francesca, i tuoi martìri 117 a lagrimar mi fanno tristo e pio.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Then I turned to them and spoke, 116 and began: "Francesca, your torments 117 make me weep with sadness and pity.
**Cornish:**
115 Wosa henna, me a droas orth ha nen, 116 ha kovsa: "Franseska, dha boesow martri 117 a wra dha dhywghyn trist ha pious."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Ma dimmi: al tempo d’i dolci sospiri, 119 a che e come concedette amore 120 che conosceste i dubbiosi disiri?».
query.result:
**English:**
118 But tell me: in the time of sweet sighs, 119 how and in what way did love concede 120 that you should know your doubtful desires?
**Cornish:**
118 Mes dywedh: y'n termyn an dowr dowrus, 119 pyth ha pyth a-gannasas karanteth 120 dhe dhyskasowgh an dowts an gannasowgh?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 E quella a me: «Nessun maggior dolore 122 che ricordarsi del tempo felice 123 nella miseria; e ciò sa ’l tuo dottore.
query.result:
**English:**
121 And she to me: "There is no greater sorrow 122 than to recall a happy time 123 in misery; and this your teacher knows."
**Cornish:**
121 Ha henna dhym: "Nyns eus poen moy 122 ages kovy dhe'n eurys termyn 123 yn an govyans; ha henna a wydh dhodh doktor."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Ma s’a conoscer la prima radice 125 del nostro amor tu hai cotanto affetto, 126 dirò come colui che piange e dice.
query.result:
**English:**
124 But if you have such a desire 125 to know the first root 126 of our love, I will tell you as one who weeps and speaks.
**Cornish:**
124 Mes agas kar dhe dhyskons an kynsa gwreydh 125 a'gan karanteth, ty a'th eus kemmys affection, 126 vyth wra vyth leverel ha leverel avel onan a wela ha kewsel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Noi leggiavamo un giorno per diletto 128 di Lancialotto come amor lo strinse; 129 soli eravamo e sanza alcun sospetto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 One day we read for pleasure 128 of Lancelot, how love constrained him; 129 we were alone and without any suspicion.
**Cornish:**
127 Nyns onan dydh ny a'n leveris 128 a-dro Lanselot, pena'gas carow; 129 onan o ny ha'n neb aral.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Per più fïate li occhi ci sospinse 131 quella lettura, e scolorocci il viso; 132 ma solo un punto fu quel che ci vinse.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Quando leggemmo il disïato riso 134 esser basciato da cotanto amante, 135 questi, che mai da me non fia diviso,
136 la bocca mi basciò tutto tremante.
query.result:
**English:**
133 When we read how the longed-for smile 134 was kissed by such a lover, 135 this man, who will never be parted from me,
136 kissed my mouth, trembling all over.
**Cornish:**
133 Pyth pan leuvras an geryow desyrys 134 bosyes genys gans karador meur, 135 hemma, nag eus veur bythkwethyes,
136 a bosyas ow genys ow tymmla gans dowr.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
137 Galeotto fu ’l libro e chi lo scrisse: 138 quel giorno più non vi leggemmo avante».
139 Mentre che l’uno spirto questo disse, 140 l’altro piangëa; sì che di pietade 141 io venni men così com’ io morisse.
query.result:
**English:**
137 Galeotto was the book and he who wrote it: 138 that day we read no further.
139 While the one spirit said this, 140 the other wept; so that with pity 141 I fainted, as if I were dying.
**Cornish:**
137 Galeotto veu an lyver ha’y skrifas: 138 henna dhew nyns eus ni leveris moy.
139 Pan wrug an eyl yma leverel henna, 140 an eyl aral o wehlas; rag wosa 141 yth fynnav vy dhesempys, kepar ha bos marow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 E caddi come corpo morto cade.
query.result: **English:**142 And I fell as a dead body falls.**Cornish:**142 Ha kolon vy dhevel marow kolon vy.**
